Evening :)
 
 There are some very interesting responses on your webpage; most thought-provoking.
 
 One statement did rather leap out at me, however:
 
 
Every theologian, even every atheist, would probably agree with you that religions are based on faith. That is a starting point, like an axiom in mathematics. 

 
 I could either agree or disagree on this point, depending upon what was meant by 'based on'.
 
 If you're talking about the initial spark that fired a religion - say, the belief in a narrative justification for a possibly coincidental event - then yes, I'd agree. I'd also point out that everything we broadly think of as 'scientific knowledge' ultimately began the same way: the belief (or at least suspicion) that some consistent mechanism links certain events. Whether you end up with science or religion depends entirely upon what you do next.
 
 At least one of the paragraphs on your page attempts to segregate on principle the scientific from the personal, mechanism from narrative, explanations from justifications. This is in my opinion a false separation. It is an entirely testable proposition that, for example, the meek shall inherit the earth, or that cheats never prosper, or indeed any consistent assertion regardless of whether it demands the universe uphold some narrative imperative. The impersonality of science has emerged, just like any other law or equation, from the process of performing science. It models the world mathematically rather than dramatically because that's what works.
 
 If, alternatively, you are claiming that religions are axiomatically based upon faith in the sense of faith being, to put it crudely, 'the point of' religion, I would strongly disagree, for three reasons:
 
 First, referring to the point made above, it is perfectly possible to scientifically establish universal narrative laws. They need only be testable and consistent. Thus a spiritual journey - the discovery of individual or collective purpose, say - can in principle be made without faith. I'm no bible scholar, for instance, but I don't recall any of the main protagonists needing to have faith in anything that wasn't fairly promptly confirmed.
 
 Which leads me to my second reason, namely that the faith upon which modern religions subsist is not the same faith of which they were born, upon which they are truly based. The primal faith of Religion was the same faith with which I turn the key in the ignition each morning - or better yet, the faith which prevents some people from walking beneath ladders or smashing mirrors. It was faith in appreciable, inescapable and more-or-less immediate consequences.
 
 These days, such faith is comparatively rare - and where it survives, it generally does so as the gaudy fair-weather bloom of a hardier, all but ineradicable growth of untestable beliefs beneath. Thus someone will maintain confidence in the healing power of prayer, for example, whilst placing the failure of such genuine, tangible events to affect the average in the realm of divine mystery.
 
 It is quite wrong, then, to suggest that faith - belief in the absence of proof - is axiomatic to Religion or even foundational to religions extant today. On the contrary: pure faith is - and not through choice - their last refuge.
